root-bootstrap.name: IdiamPro Bootstrap Plan
root-bootstrap.content: A practical roadmap for launching IdiamPro as a solo developer with minimal upfront investment. This plan focuses on building momentum before spending money, validating market demand, and scaling only when revenue supports it.

phase-1.name: Phase 1: Establish Web Presence (Cost: ~$50/year)
phase-1.content: Focus on creating a professional online presence with minimal investment. The goal is to have a landing page that can capture interest and validate demand before investing in development infrastructure.

p1-domain.name: Register Domain (~$12/year)
p1-domain.content:
Action: Register idiampro.com (or similar) through a registrar like Namecheap, Porkbun, or Google Domains.

Why it matters: A professional domain establishes credibility. Use it for your website and email.

Budget tip: Avoid premium domains. A .com is ideal, but .app or .io work for tech products.

p1-landing.name: Create Landing Page (Free)
p1-landing.content:
Free options:

  • GitHub Pages: Host your Next.js export for free
  • Vercel: Free tier for personal projects, includes SSL
  • Netlify: Similar free tier with good performance

What to include:

  • Clear value proposition (AI-native outlining)
  • Feature highlights with screenshots
  • Email signup for waitlist/updates
  • Link to app store when ready

Tool recommendations: Use the existing Next.js codebase to create a marketing site, or use a simple HTML template.

p1-social.name: Social Media Presence (Free)
p1-social.content:
Essential platforms:

  • Twitter/X: Best for developer tools and tech products
  • LinkedIn: Professional network, good for B2B features
  • Product Hunt: Create profile now, plan launch later

Content strategy:

  • Share development progress (build in public)
  • Post tips about outlining/productivity
  • Engage with productivity tool communities

Time investment: 30 min/day maximum at start

p1-analytics.name: Set Up Analytics (Free)
p1-analytics.content:
Free tools:

  • Google Analytics 4: Industry standard, free forever
  • Plausible/Fathom: Privacy-focused alternatives (paid but cheap)
  • Hotjar free tier: For understanding user behavior

What to track:

  • Landing page visits and bounce rate
  • Email signups
  • Geographic distribution of interest

Why it matters: Data helps validate demand before spending on development.

phase-2.name: Phase 2: App Store Preparation (Cost: $99-$125/year)
phase-2.content: Before submitting to app stores, understand the requirements and costs. Start with one platform to minimize upfront investment.

p2-apple.name: Apple Developer Program ($99/year)
p2-apple.content:
What you get:

  • iOS App Store distribution
  • Mac App Store distribution (same membership)
  • TestFlight for beta testing
  • Access to Apple frameworks and APIs

Requirements:

  • Apple ID (personal is fine to start)
  • Any Mac for development (even a Mac Mini)
  • No business entity required initially

Key insight: Many successful indie apps are published under personal developer accounts. You can transfer to a company later.

Review process: Apple review typically takes 24-48 hours. Budget extra time for first submission.

p2-mac.name: Mac App Store vs Direct Distribution
p2-mac.content:
Mac App Store pros:

  • Built-in discovery and trust
  • Automatic updates
  • Same $99 developer fee as iOS

Mac App Store cons:

  • 30% revenue share
  • Sandboxing restrictions
  • Review delays

Direct distribution alternative:

  • Sell through your website (Gumroad, Paddle, etc.)
  • Only 5-10% payment processing fee
  • Requires notarization ($99 Apple Developer still needed)
  • More control over updates and pricing

Recommendation: Start with Mac App Store for credibility, add direct sales later for better margins.

p2-web-first.name: Web App Strategy (Free/Cheap)
p2-web-first.content:
Why start with web:

  • No app store approval required
  • Instant updates without review
  • Works on all platforms immediately
  • Can validate product-market fit before native investment

Hosting options:

  • Vercel: Free tier generous for starting out
  • Railway: $5/month after free tier
  • Fly.io: Free tier with good performance

Monetization:

  • Stripe for payments (2.9% + 30¢ per transaction)
  • No platform fee beyond payment processing

Strategy: Launch web app first, gather feedback, then package for app stores.

p2-android.name: Google Play Store ($25 one-time)
p2-android.content:
Cost: One-time $25 registration fee (much cheaper than Apple's annual fee)

When to consider:

  • After iOS version is stable
  • If analytics show Android user demand
  • Capacitor makes cross-platform relatively easy

Caution: Android fragmentation can increase support burden. Consider delaying until you have revenue to justify the time investment.

Alternative: Web app (PWA) works well on Android without Play Store presence.

phase-3.name: Phase 3: Validate Before Scaling
phase-3.content: The most expensive mistake is building something nobody wants. This phase focuses on validation with minimal spend.

p3-beta.name: Beta Testing Strategy
p3-beta.content:
TestFlight (iOS):

  • Up to 10,000 external testers free
  • 90-day builds, then need to update
  • Great for gathering feedback before public launch

Finding beta testers:

  • Productivity tool subreddits (r/productivity, r/getdisciplined)
  • Twitter build-in-public community
  • Indie Hackers forum
  • Friends and family (but be cautious of biased feedback)

What to ask:

  • What's confusing?
  • What's missing?
  • Would you pay for this? How much?

p3-feedback.name: Feedback Collection (Free)
p3-feedback.content:
Free tools:

  • Google Forms: Simple surveys
  • Typeform free tier: More engaging surveys
  • In-app feedback: Simple email link works
  • GitHub Issues: For bug reports and feature requests

What to track:

  • Most requested features
  • Friction points in onboarding
  • Use cases you didn't anticipate

Key insight: Pay attention to what users DO, not just what they SAY. Usage analytics matter more than surveys.

p3-pricing.name: Pricing Validation
p3-pricing.content:
Before committing to a price:

  • Research competitor pricing (Notion, Obsidian, Roam)
  • Test different price points with different beta groups
  • Consider freemium vs paid-only

Common indie pricing models:

  • Freemium: Free basic, $5-15/month premium
  • One-time purchase: $29-99 (Mac apps)
  • Annual subscription: $49-99/year

Recommendation for bootstrap: Start with a simple free tier + one paid tier. You can always add complexity later.

p3-metrics.name: Key Metrics to Track
p3-metrics.content:
Before spending money, validate these:

  • Daily Active Users (DAU): Are people coming back?
  • Retention: What % return after Day 1, Day 7, Day 30?
  • Feature usage: What features actually get used?
  • Conversion intent: How many ask about pricing?

Tools (all have free tiers):

  • Mixpanel, Amplitude, or PostHog for product analytics
  • Simple server-side logging if privacy is a concern

Rule of thumb: If 10% of free users show buying intent, you have something worth investing in.

phase-4.name: Phase 4: Launch and Early Revenue
phase-4.content: Once validated, focus on generating revenue to fund further development. Stay lean until revenue consistently covers costs.

p4-soft-launch.name: Soft Launch Strategy
p4-soft-launch.content:
What is a soft launch: Release to a limited audience before the big marketing push.

Benefits:

  • Catch bugs before they hurt reviews
  • Refine onboarding based on real usage
  • Build initial reviews/ratings
  • Test payment flow with real transactions

How to soft launch:

  • iOS: Release to specific countries first (e.g., Canada)
  • Web: Share only with beta testers and email list
  • Gather 20-50 reviews before full marketing push

p4-product-hunt.name: Product Hunt Launch (Free)
p4-product-hunt.content:
Why Product Hunt matters:

  • Free exposure to early adopters
  • Credibility boost ("Featured on Product Hunt")
  • Potential press coverage
  • Backlinks for SEO

Preparation:

  • Have polished screenshots and video ready
  • Prepare for traffic spike (ensure servers can handle it)
  • Line up supporters to upvote at launch
  • Be available to answer comments all day

Timing: Launch on Tuesday-Thursday for best visibility. Avoid Mondays and weekends.

p4-content-marketing.name: Content Marketing (Free)
p4-content-marketing.content:
Free distribution channels:

  • Blog posts: Host on your site, share on Medium
  • YouTube: Tutorial videos, feature walkthroughs
  • Reddit: Provide value first, promote subtly
  • Hacker News: Launch blog post or Show HN

Content ideas:

  • "How I built X feature" (dev community loves this)
  • Productivity tips using outlining
  • Comparison guides (IdiamPro vs Notion, etc.)

Key principle: Provide value first. Direct promotion without value gets downvoted.

p4-first-revenue.name: Path to First $1,000 MRR
p4-first-revenue.content:
Revenue milestones:

  • $0-100/month: Validation phase - are people willing to pay?
  • $100-500/month: Cover basic costs (hosting, tools)
  • $500-1000/month: Sustainable indie project
  • $1000+/month: Consider reinvesting in growth

To reach $1000 MRR at $10/month:

  • Need 100 paying customers
  • At 2% conversion from free, need 5,000 free users
  • Focus on retention as much as acquisition

Key insight: 100 happy paying customers is better than 1,000 unhappy free users.

phase-5.name: Phase 5: Scale When Revenue Supports It
phase-5.content: Only invest in these when revenue consistently exceeds basic costs. Premature scaling kills bootstrapped businesses.

p5-when-llc.name: When to Form an LLC
p5-when-llc.content:
You DON'T need an LLC to:

  • Publish on App Store (personal developer account is fine)
  • Accept payments (Stripe works with individuals)
  • Have a website and business presence

Consider an LLC when:

  • Revenue exceeds $5,000/month consistently
  • You want liability protection
  • Business bank account becomes necessary
  • Tax benefits outweigh formation costs

LLC costs:

  • Formation: $50-500 depending on state
  • Annual fees: $0-800 depending on state (California is expensive)
  • Registered agent: $50-150/year if needed

Cheapest states: Wyoming, Delaware, New Mexico (for non-residents)

p5-when-paid.name: When to Pay for Tools
p5-when-paid.content:
Stay free as long as possible:

  • Free tiers are generous for small projects
  • Paid features often aren't needed at low scale
  • Upgrading is easy when you need to

Worth paying for early:

  • Domain name (~$12/year) - non-negotiable
  • Apple Developer ($99/year) - if doing iOS
  • Reliable email (Google Workspace $6/month) - when you need custom domain email

Delay until revenue supports:

  • Premium analytics tools
  • Advanced monitoring
  • Paid marketing/advertising
  • Professional services (legal, accounting)

p5-when-hire.name: When to Get Help
p5-when-hire.content:
Before hiring/contracting:

  • Revenue should cover the cost 3x over
  • You should be turning away work/opportunities
  • The task should be clearly defined

First hires/contracts (in order):

  1. Bookkeeper: When taxes become complex ($50-200/month)
  2. Customer support: When support takes >10 hrs/week
  3. Designer: For marketing assets (project-based)
  4. Developer: Only when you're the bottleneck

Alternatives to hiring:

  • Automate with tools before hiring humans
  • Use AI for first-draft content, support responses
  • Outsource one-time tasks on Fiverr/Upwork

p5-reinvest.name: Reinvestment Priority
p5-reinvest.content:
When you have profit, reinvest in this order:

  1. Reliability: Better hosting, monitoring, backups
  2. User experience: Design improvements, performance
  3. Marketing: Content, SEO, selective ads
  4. Features: Only features users are asking for
  5. Platform expansion: Android, new markets

The bootstrap mindset:

  • Every dollar should generate more than a dollar back
  • Measure ROI on every expense
  • Stay profitable even while growing

legal-structures.name: Legal Structures: What You Actually Need
legal-structures.content: Many developers over-complicate legal setup. Here's what actually matters at each stage.

legal-solo.name: Sole Proprietor (Starting Out)
legal-solo.content:
What it means: You and your business are the same legal entity. No formation required.

For App Store:

  • Apple accepts individual developers
  • Your personal name appears as "seller"
  • This is fine for starting out

Pros:

  • Zero cost to start
  • Simplest tax filing (Schedule C)
  • No annual fees or filings

Cons:

  • No liability protection
  • Harder to get business credit
  • Less "professional" appearance

When it works: Revenue under $5K/month, no significant liability concerns, just you working on it.

legal-llc.name: LLC (Growth Stage)
legal-llc.content:
What it means: A separate legal entity that provides liability protection while being tax-efficient for small businesses.

Benefits:

  • Personal assets protected from business liability
  • Pass-through taxation (no double tax)
  • Professional appearance
  • Easier to get business banking

Costs:

  • Formation: $50-500 (state filing fees)
  • Annual fees: Vary by state ($0-$800)
  • Operating agreement: DIY is fine for single-member

Best states for single-member LLC:

  • Wyoming: No state income tax, $100 formation, $60/year
  • New Mexico: $50 formation, no annual report
  • Delaware: Good case law, but $300/year fee

Note: If you live in a state with LLC tax (like California $800/year), you may need to file there regardless of where you form.

legal-corp.name: Corporation (When You Need It)
legal-corp.content:
When to consider a C-Corp:

  • Taking venture capital investment
  • Offering stock options to employees
  • Revenue exceeding $100K+ and complex tax situation

Why NOT to start as a C-Corp:

  • Double taxation on profits
  • More expensive to maintain ($1,000+/year)
  • Annual meetings, board minutes required
  • Overkill for solo bootstrapped business

The conversion path:

  • Start as sole proprietor
  • Form LLC when revenue justifies it
  • Convert to C-Corp only if raising investment

This path lets you stay lean while preserving options.

legal-mistakes.name: Expensive Mistakes to Avoid
legal-mistakes.content:
Don't do these too early:

  • Forming in Delaware when you live elsewhere: You'll need to register in your home state anyway, doubling fees
  • Paying lawyers for boilerplate: Standard Terms of Service and Privacy Policy templates are fine to start
  • Getting a trademark before validating: $250-400 per class, wait until you're sure of the name
  • Over-engineering contracts: Simple agreements work until you have significant revenue

Do protect yourself:

  • Keep business and personal finances separate
  • Document decisions and agreements (even informal ones)
  • Have basic Terms of Service and Privacy Policy
  • Get liability insurance when you can afford it ($300-500/year)

revenue-strategy.name: Revenue Strategy for Solo Developer
revenue-strategy.content: Focus on sustainable revenue that doesn't require massive scale to be worthwhile.

rev-pricing.name: Pricing Strategy
rev-pricing.content:
Pricing philosophy for indie apps:

  • Price for sustainability, not maximum revenue
  • Higher price = fewer customers = less support burden
  • It's easier to lower prices than raise them

Recommended starting point:

  • Free tier: Core features, limited AI usage
  • Pro tier: $8-12/month or $79-99/year
  • Annual discount: Equivalent to 2 months free

Comparison:

  • Notion: Free / $8/month / $15/month
  • Obsidian: Free / $50/year sync / $25/year publish
  • Roam: $15/month (no free tier)

Key insight: 100 customers at $10/month = $12,000/year. That's a meaningful side income with manageable support load.

rev-payment.name: Payment Processing
rev-payment.content:
Platforms and their cuts:

  • App Store (iOS/Mac): 30% (15% for small business program under $1M)
  • Stripe (web): 2.9% + 30¢ per transaction
  • Paddle: 5% + 50¢ (handles sales tax/VAT)
  • Gumroad: 10% + 30¢

Recommendation:

  • Use App Store for iOS (required) and Mac (convenient)
  • Use Stripe for web subscriptions (much lower fees)
  • Consider Paddle if international sales tax is overwhelming

Small Business Program: Apple reduces cut to 15% if you made <$1M in the previous year. Apply as soon as you enroll.

rev-free-vs-paid.name: Free vs Paid Features
rev-free-vs-paid.content:
What to include in free tier:

  • Core outlining functionality
  • Local storage (no server costs)
  • Basic export (JSON, Markdown)
  • Limited AI (e.g., 10 generations/month)

What to reserve for paid:

  • Unlimited AI features (they cost you money)
  • Cloud sync (requires infrastructure)
  • PDF export (nice-to-have premium feel)
  • Advanced organization (tags, multiple workspaces)

Philosophy: Free tier should be genuinely useful. Paid tier should be "worth it" for power users. Don't cripple free just to force upgrades.

rev-goals.name: Revenue Goals and Reality Check
rev-goals.content:
Realistic timeline for bootstrapped app:

  • Month 1-3: Building and soft launch. $0 revenue is normal.
  • Month 4-6: First paying customers. Goal: $100-500 MRR
  • Month 6-12: Product-market fit. Goal: $500-2,000 MRR
  • Year 2: Sustainable side income. Goal: $2,000-5,000 MRR

What these numbers mean:

  • $500/month: Covers hosting and tools
  • $2,000/month: Meaningful side income
  • $5,000/month: Could consider going full-time
  • $10,000/month: Solid indie business

Reality: Most indie apps never reach $1,000 MRR. Success requires persistence, iteration, and luck. Plan for the journey, not just the destination.

ai-provider-costs.name: AI Provider Costs and Optimization
ai-provider-costs.content: Understanding AI API costs is critical for pricing your subscription tiers. IdiamPro uses AI for content generation, and these costs directly impact your margins.

ai-current-pricing.name: Current API Pricing (2026)
ai-current-pricing.content:
Google Gemini (currently used by IdiamPro):

ModelInputOutputBest For
Gemini 2.0 Flash~$0.10/1M tokens~$0.40/1M tokensFast, cheap, good quality
Gemini 1.5 Pro~$1.25/1M~$5.00/1MComplex reasoning

Anthropic Claude (potential alternative):

ModelInputOutputBest For
Claude Haiku$1.00/1M tokens$5.00/1M tokensFast responses, simple tasks
Claude Sonnet$3.00/1M tokens$15.00/1M tokensBest balance of cost/quality
Claude Opus$5.00/1M tokens$25.00/1M tokensComplex analysis, premium tier

Key insight: Gemini Flash is ~10x cheaper than Claude Haiku. This significantly impacts margin calculations.

ai-volume-discounts.name: Volume Discount Programs
ai-volume-discounts.content:
Google Cloud / Gemini:

  • Committed use discounts start at ~$10,000/month
  • Contact Google Cloud sales for negotiated pricing
  • Typical discounts: 10-30% based on commitment
  • Free tier: Up to 15 requests/minute on Gemini API

Anthropic / Claude:

  • Volume discounts are negotiated case-by-case
  • No published threshold; contact sales
  • Typically requires consistent high-volume usage
  • Enterprise plans include dedicated support

How to contact for discounts:

  • Google: Google Cloud Console → Support → Contact Sales
  • Anthropic: anthropic.com → Contact Sales or sales@anthropic.com

When to negotiate: Once you're spending $1,000+/month consistently, it's worth having the conversation.

ai-optimization.name: Cost Optimization Strategies
ai-optimization.content:
Batch API (both providers):

  • 50% discount for non-time-sensitive requests
  • Results delivered within 24 hours
  • Good for: Bulk content generation, background processing
  • Not good for: Interactive user requests

Prompt Caching (Claude):

  • Cache frequently-used system prompts
  • Up to 90% savings on cached content
  • Requires consistent prompt prefixes

Token optimization:

  • Keep prompts concise - every token costs money
  • Use smaller models for simple tasks
  • Set reasonable max_tokens limits

Usage limits per tier:

  • Free tier: 10-20 generations/month
  • Pro tier: 200-500 generations/month
  • Unlimited: Consider fair use policy to prevent abuse

ai-subscription-design.name: Designing Subscription Tiers with 20% Margin
ai-subscription-design.content:
Cost calculation per user (example with Gemini Flash):

  • Average generation: ~1,000 input tokens + ~500 output tokens
  • Cost per generation: ~$0.0003
  • 100 generations/month: ~$0.03 per user
  • Even heavy users (~500 gens): ~$0.15 per user

Recommended tier structure with 20% margin:

TierAI Cost/UserWith 20% MarginSuggested Price
Free (10 gens)$0.003-$0
Basic (100 gens)$0.03$0.036$5/month
Pro (500 gens)$0.15$0.18$10/month
Power (unlimited*)~$0.50 avg$0.60$20/month

Key insight: With Gemini Flash, AI costs are negligible compared to subscription prices. The 20% margin is easily achieved. Your main costs will be hosting, not AI.

If adding Claude as premium option:

  • Claude Sonnet at 500 gens/month ≈ $2.70 cost
  • With 20% margin: $3.24 minimum
  • Suggested premium tier: $15-20/month for Claude access

Strategy: Offer Gemini as default (high margin), Claude as optional upgrade (premium positioning).

profitability-model.name: Profitability Model: Running at a Profit
profitability-model.content:
This chapter consolidates all costs and revenue considerations to ensure IdiamPro always operates profitably. The goal is a minimum 60% gross margin after all costs, which is healthy for a solo-developer SaaS business.

Chapter Overview:

SectionKey Takeaways
9.1 Infrastructure Costs~$42/month total; break-even at just 5 subscribers
9.2 App Store CutsYou keep 85% (app stores) or 94-97% (web/Stripe)
9.3 Cross-Platform ModelOne subscription = all platforms (best practice)
9.4 Final Tier DesignFree / $9.99 Pro / $19.99 Power with 68-88% margins
9.5 Break-Even Analysis200 subscribers = ~$2,000/month profit

Recommended Subscription Tiers:

TierPriceWhat's Included
Free$03 outlines, 10 AI generations/month, local storage
Pro$9.99/mo or $99/yearUnlimited outlines, 200 AI gens, cloud sync, PDF export, ALL platforms
Power$19.99/mo or $199/yearEverything in Pro + unlimited AI, Claude access, priority support

Bottom Line: The business is profitable from subscriber #5 onward, with 68-88% gross margins across all tiers.

prof-infrastructure.name: Infrastructure Running Costs
prof-infrastructure.content:
Fixed Annual Costs:

ItemCostNotes
Apple Developer Program$99/yearRequired for iOS + Mac App Store
Domain Registration$12/yearidiampro.com or similar
Google Play (one-time)$25Amortize over 5 years = $5/year
Total Fixed~$116/year~$10/month

Variable/Scaling Costs:

ServiceFree TierPaid TierWhen to Upgrade
Vercel Hosting100GB bandwidth$20/month>1,000 daily users
AI APIs (Gemini)Limited~$0.03-0.50/user/moScales with usage
Email (Google Workspace)Gmail works$6/monthWhen you need @idiampro.com
Analytics (PostHog/Mixpanel)Generous free$0-50/month>10,000 events/month

First Year Budget (Conservative):

  • Fixed costs: $116
  • Hosting (assuming upgrade): $240
  • Email: $72
  • AI APIs (100 users avg): ~$60
  • Total: ~$500/year or ~$42/month

Break-even: Just 5 subscribers at $10/month covers all infrastructure.

prof-app-store-cuts.name: App Store Revenue Shares
prof-app-store-cuts.content:
What You Actually Receive:

PlatformStandard CutSmall Business RateYou Receive
Apple App Store30%15% (under $1M/year)85% of price
Google Play30%15% (first $1M/year)85% of price
Web (Stripe)2.9% + $0.30Same~94-97% of price
Web (Paddle)5% + $0.50Same~90-95% of price

Revenue by Channel (at $10/month subscription):

ChannelUser PaysPlatform TakesYou Receive
iOS App Store$10.00$1.50$8.50
Google Play$10.00$1.50$8.50
Web (Stripe)$10.00$0.59$9.41

Small Business Program Requirements:

  • Apple: Enroll at developer.apple.com/programs/small-business - auto-qualifies if under $1M previous year
  • Google: Automatic for first $1M in each calendar year

Strategy: Web subscriptions yield 10-11% more revenue than app store subscriptions. Consider offering a small discount for web signups to encourage this path.

prof-cross-platform.name: Cross-Platform Subscription Model
prof-cross-platform.content:
Best Practice: One Subscription = All Platforms

Modern users expect their subscription to work everywhere. Charging separately per platform creates friction and frustration.

Recommended Model:

  • User subscribes once (via any platform)
  • Subscription unlocks iOS, Mac, Web, and future Android
  • Account-based authentication syncs subscription status

Implementation:

  • Create user accounts (email + password or OAuth)
  • Store subscription status on your server
  • Each platform checks subscription status via API
  • Use RevenueCat or similar to unify app store subscriptions

RevenueCat (Recommended):

  • Free up to $2,500 MTR (monthly tracked revenue)
  • Unifies Apple, Google, and Stripe subscriptions
  • Handles receipt validation, subscription status
  • $0.01 per transaction after free tier

Why This Works:

  • Users feel they're getting value (all platforms included)
  • Reduces support burden (no "why doesn't it work on my Mac?")
  • Enables family/device flexibility
  • Competitive with Notion, Obsidian, etc.

prof-tier-design.name: Final Subscription Tier Design
prof-tier-design.content:
Recommended Tiers (All Platforms Included):

TierMonthlyAnnualFeatures
Free$0$03 outlines, 10 AI gens/month, local storage only
Pro$9.99$99/year (save 17%)Unlimited outlines, 200 AI gens/month, cloud sync, PDF export
Power$19.99$199/year (save 17%)Everything in Pro + unlimited AI, Claude access, priority support

Cost & Margin Analysis (Pro Tier at $9.99):

ItemApp StoreWeb
Revenue received$8.49$9.40
AI cost (avg user)-$0.15-$0.15
Infrastructure (per user share)-$0.50-$0.50
Gross Profit$7.84 (78%)$8.75 (88%)

Cost & Margin Analysis (Power Tier at $19.99):

ItemApp StoreWeb
Revenue received$16.99$19.11
AI cost (heavy user + Claude)-$3.00-$3.00
Infrastructure (per user share)-$0.50-$0.50
Gross Profit$13.49 (68%)$15.61 (78%)

Key Insight: Even the Power tier with Claude access maintains 68%+ gross margin. The business is highly profitable at any scale.

prof-break-even.name: Break-Even Analysis & Profit Targets
prof-break-even.content:
Monthly Fixed Costs (After Launch):

  • Infrastructure: ~$42/month (see 9.1)
  • Your time: Priceless (but free at bootstrap stage)

Break-Even Points:

ScenarioPro Users NeededPower Users NeededMixed (70/30)
Cover infrastructure ($42)6 users3 users5 users
Side income ($500/mo)64 users32 users52 users
Serious income ($2,000/mo)256 users128 users207 users
Full-time potential ($5,000/mo)640 users320 users518 users

Recommended Profit Targets:

  • Minimum gross margin: 60% (you're achieving 68-88%)
  • Target gross margin: 70%+ (easily achievable)
  • Reserve fund: Keep 3 months of operating costs in reserve

Profit Allocation Strategy:

  • First $500/month: Reinvest in infrastructure reliability
  • $500-2,000/month: 50% take home, 50% marketing/growth
  • $2,000+/month: Consider part-time transition, hire help

Bottom Line: With ~200 paying subscribers at a 70/30 Pro/Power mix, you'll earn ~$2,000/month profit. The math works. Focus on building a product people love and the revenue will follow.
